Key Arguments: The bill is seen as a form of censorship, concentrating power in the hands of the government.
There is skepticism about who defines 'misinformation' and 'disinformation', with concerns about bureaucrats having too much power.
The bill exempts the government from being held accountable for spreading misinformation.
Existing laws already address harmful misinformation, making the new bill unnecessary.
The bill threatens freedom of speech and could lead to a suppression of dissenting opinions.
The legislation could breach international human rights obligations and contradict Australia's values.
Notable Quotes: Censorship is power. The one who censors takes power away from everyone else.
This is the Orwellian nightmare people have been fearingâ€”straight out of Orwell's 1984, Ministry of Truth.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental right of every Australian.
